An Introduction of Payment Terminals

A payment terminal, or Point of Sale (POS) terminal, credit card terminal, EFTPOS terminal is a device designed to make electronic transactions that interface with payment cards. The terminal typically consists of a secure keypad (called a PIN pad) for entering the PIN, a screen, a means of capturing information from payments cards, and a network connection to access the payment network for authorization---explanation of payment terminal by Wikipedia.

There are the basic functions of a general payment terminal in the industry:

> Key entry (for the customer not present mail and telephone order)

> Tips/gratuities

> Refunds and adjustments

> Settlement (including automatic)

> Pre-authorization

> Payments using near field communication-enabled devices

> Remote initialization and software update

> Point of sale (POS) integration

> Multi-merchant capabilities

> Pen or PIN authorization by the customer

> Surcharge function

> Secure password operation

> Additional PIN pad attachments

We have sorted out a concise history of the payment terminal.

- 1979: Point of sale terminals emerged; Magnetic stripes were added to credit cards for the first time. That allowed card information to be captured electronically and led to the development of payment terminals.

- 1980: Jean-Jacques Poutrel and Michel Malhouitre established Ingenico in France and developed their first payment terminal in 1984.

- 1981: Verifone started as a small electronic company in Hawaii to produce payment terminals.

- 1983: They introduced the ZON terminal series, which would become the standard for modern payment terminals.

- 1978: Verifone’s rival Hypercom was established in 1978.

- 1982: Hypercom started producing dedicated payment terminals.

- 1994: Lipman Electronic Engineering, Ltd. was established in Israel. Lipman manufactured the Nurit line of processing terminals.

-2006 & 2011: The payment terminal business expanded. Verifone acquired Lipman in 2006 and the payment part of the Hypercom business including its brand in 2011.

In the late 1990s and early 2000s: Contactless payment systems were introduced and the payment terminals were updated to include the ability to read these cards using near field communication (NFC) technology.
